revision.text:
The '''St. John's University strike of 1966-1967''' was a [[strike action|strike]] by faculty at [[St. John's University (New York City)|St. John's University]] in [[New York City]] which began on January 4, 1966, and ended in June 1967. The strike began after 31 faculty members were dismissed in the fall of 1965 without due process, dismissals which some felt were a violation of the professors' [[academic freedom]]. The strike ended without any reinstatements, but led to the widespread unionization of public college faculty in the New York City area.
==Cause of the strike== In the fall of 1965, 31 faculty members at St. John's University were dismissed without due process or any hearing. Both the [[American Association of University Professors]] (AAUP) and the [[United Federation of College Teachers]] (UFCT) claimed the university had violated the professors' academic freedom. St. John's, the two groups said, demanded that the faculty restrict their teaching to a narrow, dogmatic approach to [[Thomism]] and required faculty to submit all articles and books to the administration for clearance before seeking publication. The Rev. [[Joseph T. Cahill]], president of St. John's, said the teachers had used their classrooms for propaganda purposes.<ref name="Strife">"Strife at St. John's," ''Time,'' December 31, 1965.</ref><ref>Currivan, "St. John's Hints Faculty Conduct Led to Ousters," ''New York Times,'' December 23, 1965.</ref>
The president of the UFCT, [[Israel Kugler]], pushed for a more radical response to the dispute. The AAUP refused to engage in a strike, and largely withdrew from the dispute when faculty appeared to support Kugler. Kugler called for a strike to begin in January 1966, and widened the dispute to include pay and benefits (faculty pay was the lowest of the 10 largest Catholic universities in the U.S.<ref name="Strife" />
==The strike begins== The strike at St. John's started on January 4, 1966. The union pushed for mediation and arbitration in December 1965, but the university refused to submit to either. Using tactics pioneered by [[Albert Shanker]] to win collective bargaining rights for New York City public school teachers, Kugler pushed for local and state government officials to get involved in the dispute. Only a minority of St. John's faculty walked out, forcing the university to close some but not a majority of classes.<ref>Currivan, "St. John's Strike on Jan. 3 Called By Teacher Union," ''New York Times,'' December 18, 1965; Currivan, "St. John's Gets Mediation Offer," ''New York Times,'' December 24, 1965; Currivan, "St. John's Bars Mediation By City," ''New York Times,'' December 28, 1965; Grutzner, "Mayor Offers Aid on St. Johns," ''New York Times,'' January 4, 1966; Currivan, "St. John's Opens Despite Its Strike," ''New York Times,'' January 5, 1966; Currivan, "St. John's Warns 25 Absentees to Return to Job or Face Action," ''New York Times,'' January 6, 1966; Dallos, "St. John's Calls Boycott Failure," ''New York Times,'' January 11, 1966; Gansberg, "St. John's Strike Closes Classes, But 2 Sides Disagree on Number," ''New York Times,'' February 15, 1966.</ref>
During the next two years, Kugler challenged the university's accreditation before the [[Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools]] twice. But that body only warned the university and took no further action.<ref>Dallos, "St. John's to Keep Its Accreditation But Gets Warning," ''New York Times,'' May 1, 1966; Currivan, "St. John's Warned Its Accreditation May Be Revoked," ''New York Times,'' December 2, 1966; Currivan, "St. John's Retains Its Accreditation," ''New York Times,'' May 4, 1968.</ref>
The union raised $250,000 from the [[Arbeter Ring (Workmen's Circle)|Workmen's Circle]] and other organizations to support the striking faculty. Kugler took professors' case to the [[Holy See|Vatican]] and sought an individual audience with [[Pope Paul VI]], whose encyclicals on workers' rights were repeatedly cited by the union. But the pope refused him an audience.<ref name="Forward">"Featherman File," ''The Forward,'' March 27, 1998.</ref>
Other tactics were tried as well. Some faculty sued the university for fraud for including their names in the 1966 catalog of classes.<ref>Kaplan, "Faculty Strikers Suing St. John's," ''New York Times,'' June 2, 1966; Currivan, "$100,000 Sought in St. John's Case," ''New York Times,'' October 12, 1969.</ref> Pickets went up at the spring 1966 commencement and the fall 1966 opening convocation.<ref>Dallos, "Teachers Protest at St. John's Commencement," ''New York Times,'' June 13, 1966; Currivan, "St. John's Reopening Today With Faculty Strikers Resuming Picket Line," ''New York Times,'' September 19, 1966.</ref>
==The strike ends== In the early spring of 1967, as the strike threatened to widen to other Catholic universities in the country and state legislators opened hearings on the labor dispute, the university agreed to arbitration.<ref>Morris, "Catholic U. Classes Stopped as Protest Spreads in Faculty," ''New York Times,'' April 21, 1967; Johnston, "Legislative Panel Will Investigate Sale by L.I.U. and Dismissals at St. John's," ''New York Times,'' October 10, 1967.</ref>
The strike ended in June 1967. The union did not win recognition at St. John's, and in 1970 arbitrators ruled that the university had not acted improperly.<ref>"New Impasse Stalls Plans to Arbitrate St. John's Dispute," ''New York Times,'' April 6, 1967; Gansberg, "St. John's Dispute to Be Arbitrated," ''New York Times,'' June 20, 1967; Malcolm, "Arbitrators Absolve St. John's of Teachers' Antiunion Charge," ''New York Times,'' January 28, 1970.</ref>
==Assessment and outcomes== Although the strike was a failure in that it did not win reinstatement for the faculty, the strike established the AFT as the pre-eminent union organizing American higher education faculty.<ref name="Forward" /> Kugler quickly turned the UFCT's attention to other colleges and universities in the New York City area. In the next few years, under his leadership the union organized locals at the [[Fashion Institute of Technology]] (FIT), [[Nassau Community College]] and [[Westchester Community College]].<ref name="Hevesi">Hevesi, "Israel Kugler, Union Official Who Led Strike at St. John’s, Dies at 90," ''New York Times,'' October 8, 2007.</ref> In 1967, Kugler began pushing for the UFCT to organize the faculty at CUNY. Backed by the AFT and the newly formed (and politically powerful) [[United Federation of Teachers]], UFCT not only won an agreement for a union election but won the December 6, 1968, election in the face of a determined challenge from the AAUP. The union won a second election (this time for non-[[tenure]]d faculty) nine days later, and a signed contract nine months later.<ref>Polishook, "Collective Bargaining and the City University of New York," ''Journal of Higher Education,'' May 1970.</ref><ref>Farber, "City U. Election On Union Stalled," ''New York Times,'' May 12, 1968; Clarity, "Union Wins Vote of C.U. Faculty," ''New York Times,'' December 7, 1968; Hechinger, "City U. Faculty to Cast 2d Vote On Union to Represent 4,500," ''New York Times,'' December 16, 1968; Handler, "City U. and Untenured Teachers Reach Agreement on a Contract," ''New York Times,'' September 11, 1969.</ref>
In 1972, Kugler merged the UFCT with its long-time rival, the [[Legislative Conference of the City University]]. The two groups formed a new organization affiliated with the AFT, the Professional Staff Congress (PSC). As of 2007, the PSC represented more than 20,000 faculty and staff members at CUNY.<ref name="Hevesi" />
Kugler later wrote a well-regarded article about the strike, "The 1966 Strike at St. John's University: A Memoir," which was published in ''[[Labor's Heritage]]'' in 1997.

BOX 17 |district = |postcode = |postalcode = |country = [[Ghana]] |coordinates = |schoolnumber = 0322222305 |schoolboard = |authority = |religion = [[Anglicanism]] |denomination = |oversight = [[Ministry of Education (Ghana)|Ministry of Education]] |affiliation = |authorizer = |superintendent = |trustee = |founder = |specialist = |session = |president = |head of school = |headteacher = |head_label = Headmistress |head = Felicia Osei Manu |principal = |dean = |faculty = |administrator = |rector = |chaplain = |director = |staff = |ranking = |roll = |school code = |testaverage = |national_ranking = |classrooms = |class = |classes offered = Business, general arts, general science, home economics, visual arts |avg_class_size = 30 |ratio = |graduates = |gender = Girls |lower_age = 14 |upper_age = 18 |houses = 6 |fundingtype = |type = [[Public school (government funded)|Public]] [[high school]] |system = |fees = |tuition = |revenue = |endowment = |budget = |products = |age range = |grades = |medium = |language = English |campus = |campus size = |campus type = |hours_in_day = |athletics = |conference = |slogan = "St Monica, Mother of Saints/ Each For All, All For God" |song = "As we listen down the ages" |fightsong = |motto = ''Causa Conscientae''
(Conscious cause) |accreditation = |rival = |mascot image = |sports = |patron = |nickname = Munche |school_colours = [[Blue (color)|Blue]] and [[White (color)|white]] |mascot = |yearbook = |publication = |newspaper = |established = {{start date and age|1946|paren=yes}} |status = Active |students = |pupils = |alumni = |enrollment = |grade9 = |grade10 = |grade11 = |grade12 = |other = |communities = |feeders = |website = }} '''St. Monica's Senior High School''', popularly known at '''Munche''' (Monica's), is a girls' second-cycle institution in [[Mampong]] in the [[Ashanti Region]] of [[Ghana]].{{Cite web| author = Staff | date = 14 July 2011 | title = St. Monica's SHS Excels |url = http://thechronicle.com.gh/st-monica%E2%80%99s-shs-excels| work = [[The Ghanaian Chronicle]] |access-date = 10 June 2016}} ==Location== The school can be located on the Kumasi-Mampong Highway. It is {{convert|40|km|abbr=off}} from [[Kumasi]] and lies on a hilly area thus the area is always cold. It is bounded on the north by the [[Ghana Highways Authority]], Mampong; on the south by the [[List of hospitals in the Ashanti Region|Mampong Municipal Hospital]]; on the east by Mampong Babies' Home; and on the west by the Ejura-Mampong Highway. ==History== The school's history is traced to Rt Rev [[John Aglionby (bishop)|John Orfeur Aglionby]], the [[Anglican Diocese of Accra|Anglican Bishop of the Gold Coast]] whose missionary work birthed the Convent of Our Lady and Saint Monica. In 1926, the bishop invited the sisters of the [[Order of the Holy Paraclete]] (England) to set up a school for girl-child education. ==See also== {{portal|Anglicanism|Ghana|Schools}} * [[Christianity in Ghana]] * [[Education in Ghana]] * [[List of senior high schools in the Ashanti Region]] {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Ghana high schools|state=collapsed}} {{coord missing|Ghana}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saint Monica's Senior High School}} [[Category:1920s establishments in Gold Coast (British colony)]] [[Category:1926 establishments in Africa]] [[Category:Anglican schools in Africa]] [[Category:Ashanti Region]] [[Category:Christian schools in Ghana]] [[Category:Girls' schools in Ghana]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1926]] [[Category:High schools in Ghana]] [[Category:Public schools]] {{Ghana-school-stub}} {{Anglican-stub}}

[[Maaja Nagel]]
[[Tiit Naarits]]
and others |employees = |grades = 0–12 |age range = |students = 975 |classes = |avg_class_size = primary school - 24 pupils; high school (gymnasium) - 32 pupils |ratio = |system = |classes offered = |language = [[Estonian language|Estonian]] |hours_in_day = |classrooms = |houses = 1 |accreditation = |national_ranking = |publication = |newspaper = Postipoiss |endowment = |budget = |revenue = |communities = |affiliations = |alumni = Aadu Must; Andres Dvinjaninov; Rauno Elp |website = https://www.karlova.tartu.ee/index.php?lang=est |footnotes = }} '''Tartu Karlova Gymnaasium''' ([[Estonian language|Estonian]]: Tartu Karlova Gümnaasium; abbreviated as '''TKG''') is a [[secondary school]] in [[Tartu]], [[Estonia]]. The school was founded in 1875 by Pauline Jürgens. == History == Tartu Karlova Gymnasium is one of the oldest schools in Tartu. Its roots go back as far as 1875 when Pauline Jürgens II founded her own private school. The name and the address have changed during that time. Today's building at Lina 2 street was finished in 1925 and was known as the "Tartu City 7th Primary School". In 1967 the new part of the school was built and with new specialised music and history classes. Since then the school has been a highschool. On 1 September 1995, the name of the school was changed to the "Tartu Karlova Gymnasium".https://www.karlova.tartu.ee/index.php?linkid=72&lang=eng == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tartu Karlova Gumnaasium}} [[Category:Education in Tartu]] [[Category:Schools in Estonia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tartu]] [[Category:1870s establishments in Estonia]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1875]] {{Estonia-school-stub}}

{{primary sources|date=June 2012}} The role of the '''Welsh Language Commissioner''' ({{Lang-cy|Comisiynydd y Gymraeg}}) was created by the Welsh Language (Wales) Measure 2011 on 1 April 2012 with the appointment of [[Meri Huws]] as Wales' first Commissioner.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-politics-15186747|title=Language board chief Meri Huws is Welsh commissioner|last=|first=|date=5 October 2011|work=|access-date=18 November 2016|via=BBC News}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://languagecommissioners.org/members.php?id=9|title=About the Member - Meri Huws|last=|first=|date=|website=International Association of Language Commissioners|publisher=International Association of Language Commissioners|access-date=18 November 2016}}</ref> The Commissioner's work is politically independent.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.comisiynyddygymraeg.org/English/Law/welshlanguagemeasure2011/Pages/homewelshlanguagemeasure2011.aspx | title = Mesur y Gymraeg (Cymru) 2011 | work = | publisher = Gwefan Comisiynydd y Gymraeg | accessdate = 18 May 2012 }}</ref>
The Welsh Language Commissioner's main aim is to promote and facilitate the use of the [[Welsh language]].<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.comisiynyddygymraeg.org/English/Commissioner/Pages/Aim.aspx | title = Aim of the Welsh Language Commissioner | work = | publisher = Gwefan Comisiynydd y Gymraeg | accessdate = 18 May 2012 }}</ref> This entails raising awareness of the official status of the Welsh language in Wales and by imposing standards on organisations.<ref name=":0" /> This, in turn, will lead to the establishment of rights for Welsh speakers.
According to the Commissioner's [[website]], there are two principles that underpin the work of the Commissioner, namely, * Welsh should not be treated less favourably than the [[English language]] in Wales * People should be able to live their lives in Wales through the medium of Welsh if they so wish.
== The Commissioner's Role == The Commissioner may do anything she considers appropriate to: * Promote the use of Welsh * Facilitate the use of Welsh * Work towards ensuring that Welsh is treated no less favourably than English.
This includes promoting opportunities to use Welsh and encourage best practice in the use of Welsh by people dealing with other persons, or providing services to other persons. Areas of her work also includes legal issues, preparing and publishing reports, research, educational activities and written recommendations to Ministers of the [[Government of Wales]]. She can also give advice to people.
==See also== *[[National Assembly for Wales (Official Languages) Act 2012]]
==References== <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.comisiynyddygymraeg.org Official website of the Welsh Language Commissioner] *[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/mwa/2011/1/contents/enacted Welsh Language (Wales) Measure 2011] as enacted
[[Category:Welsh language]] [[Category:Politics of Wales]] [[Category:2012 establishments in Wales]] [[Category:Language policy]]

{{other people|William Cohen}} {{Infobox officeholder |image = William Cohen, official portrait.jpg |office = 20th [[United States Secretary of Defense]] |president = [[Bill Clinton]] |deputy = [[John Hamre]]
[[Rudy de Leon]] |term_start = January 24, 1997 |term_end = January 20, 2001 |predecessor = [[William Perry]] |successor = [[Donald Rumsfeld]] |office1 = Chair of the [[United States Senate Special Committee on Aging|Senate Aging Committee]] |term_start1 = January 4, 1995 |term_end1 = January 3, 1997 |predecessor1 = [[David Pryor]] |successor1 = [[Chuck Grassley]] |office2 = Chair of the [[United States Senate Committee on Indian Affairs|Senate Indian Affairs Committee]] |term_start2 = January 5, 1981 |term_end2 = January 3, 1983 |predecessor2 = [[John Melcher]] |successor2 = [[Mark Andrews (politician)|Mark Andrews]] |jr/sr3 = United States |state3 = [[Maine]] |term_start3 = January 3, 1979 |term_end3 = January 3, 1997 |predecessor3 = [[Bill Hathaway]] |successor3 = [[Susan Collins]] |state4 = [[Maine]] |district4 = {{ushr|ME|2|2nd}} |term_start4 = January 3, 1973 |term_end4 = January 3, 1979 |predecessor4 = [[William Hathaway|Bill Hathaway]] |successor4 = [[Olympia Snowe]] |birth_name = William Sebastian Cohen |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1940|8|28}} |birth_place = [[Bangor, Maine]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Diana Dunn (divorced 1987)
[[Janet Langhart]] (1996–present) |education = [[Bowdoin College]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Boston University]] ([[Bachelor of Laws|LLB]]) }} '''William Sebastian Cohen''' (born August 28, 1940) is an [[Politics of the United States|American politician]] and author from the [[U.S. state]] of [[Maine]]. A [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], Cohen served as both a member of the United States House of Representatives and Senate, and as [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] (1997–2001) under [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[President of the United States|President]] [[Bill Clinton]].{{cite web |url=http://history.defense.gov/Multimedia/Biographies/Article-View/Article/571281/william-s-cohen/ |title=William S. Cohen - William J. Clinton Administration |work=Office of the Secretary of Defense - Historical Office}} ==Early life and education== Cohen was born in [[Bangor, Maine]]. His mother, Clara (née Hartley), was of [[Scotch-Irish Americans|Protestant Irish]] ancestry, and his father, Reuben Cohen, was a [[Russian Jewish]] [[Immigration to the United States|immigrant]]; the two owned the Bangor Rye Bread Co.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/maine/articles/2008/05/12/mother_of_former_maine_senator_clara_cohen_dies/ |title=Mother of former Maine senator, Clara Cohen, dies |publisher=Boston.com |date=2008-05-12 |accessdate=2009-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725131922/http://www.boston.com/news/local/maine/articles/2008/05/12/mother_of_former_maine_senator_clara_cohen_dies/ |archivedate=July 25, 2012 }}{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17237962/ |title='Love in Black and White' explores race - Relationships|publisher=MSNBC|date=2007-02-20|accessdate=2009-06-11}} After graduating from Bangor High School in 1958, Cohen attended [[Bowdoin College]], graduating ''[[Latin honors|cum laude]]'' with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] [[Academic degree|degree]] in [[Latin language|Latin]] in 1962. While a student at Bowdoin, Cohen was initiated as a brother of the Kappa chapter of the [[Psi Upsilon]] Fraternity.{{cite web|title=Distinguished Alumni|url=http://www.psiu.org/alum/distinguishedalumni.html|publisher=Psi Upsilon Fraternity|accessdate=October 31, 2012}} While in high school and college, Cohen was a [[basketball]] player and was named to the Maine all-state high school and college basketball team, and at Bowdoin was inducted into the New England All-Star Hall of Fame. Cohen attended [[law school]] at the [[Boston University School of Law]], graduating with a [[Bachelor of Laws]] degree ''cum laude'' in 1965. ==Legal, academic, and early political career== He became an assistant county attorney for [[Penobscot County, Maine|Penobscot County]] (1968–1970). In 1968 he became an instructor at [[Husson College]] in Bangor, and later was an instructor in [[business administration]] at the [[University of Maine]] (1968–1972). Cohen served as the vice president of the Maine Trial Lawyers Association (1970–1972) and as a member of the Bangor School Board (1971–1972). He became a [[fellow]] at the [[Kennedy School of Government|John F. Kennedy Institute of Politics at Harvard University]] in 1972, and in 1975 was named as one of the [[United States Junior Chamber|U.S. Jaycee's]] "ten outstanding young men". Cohen was elected to the Bangor City Council (1969–1972) and served as Bangor Mayor in 1971-72. ==House of Representatives and Senate== In the [[United States House election, 1972|1972 election]], Cohen won a seat in the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]], representing [[Maine's 2nd congressional district]], succeeding [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[William Hathaway]], who was elected to the US Senate. Cohen defeated Democratic State Senator [[Elmer H. Violette]] of Van Buren. [[File:Senator William Cohen (R-ME).jpg|thumb|left|Senator William Cohen early in his career]] During his first term in Congress, Cohen became deeply involved in the [[Watergate scandal|Watergate]] investigation. As a member of the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|House Judiciary Committee]], he was one of the first Republicans to break with his party, and voted for the [[Impeachment in the United States|impeachment]] of President [[Richard Nixon]]. During this time, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine named him one of "America's 200 Future Leaders". After three terms in the House, Cohen was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1978, defeating incumbent [[William Hathaway]] in his first bid for reelection. Cohen was reelected in 1984 and 1990, serving a total of 18 years in the Senate (1979–1997). In 1990, he defeated Democrat [[Neil Rolde]]. Cohen developed a reputation as a moderate Republican with liberal views on social issues, and has been described as "a career-long maverick with a reputation for fashioning compromise out of discord."{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/govt/admin/stories/cohen120696.htm|title=Washingtonpost.com: Republican Cohen Equally at Home With Policy and Poesy|author=|date=|website=www.washingtonpost.com|accessdate=29 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1997/01/22/an-outsider-set-to-take-over-pentagon/070867aa-70a7-4ed3-bfdb-c1f162e9f507/|title=AN 'OUTSIDER' SET TO TAKE OVER PENTAGON|first=Dana|last=Priest|date=22 January 1997|publisher=|accessdate=29 March 2018|via=www.washingtonpost.com}} In 1994 Cohen investigated the federal government's process for acquiring information technology, and his report, ''Computer Chaos: Billions Wasted Buying Federal Computer Systems'', generated much discussion. He chose not to run for another Senate term in 1996; [[Susan Collins]], who had worked for Cohen, was elected to succeed him. (Former Maine senator, [[Olympia Snowe]], had also worked for Cohen while he was in the House of Representatives.){{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/maine-senators-may-not-like-each-other-much-but-they-share-love-of-state-job/2011/05/03/AFGwpn0F_story.html|title=Maine senators may not like each other much, but they share love of state, job|first=Martha|last=Sherrill|date=5 May 2011|publisher=|accessdate=29 March 2018|via=www.washingtonpost.com}} While in the Senate, Cohen served on both the [[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services|Senate Armed Services Committee]] and the [[United States Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs|Governmental Affairs Committee]] (1979–1997) and was a member of the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|Senate Intelligence Committee]] 1983–1991 and again 1995–1997, serving as Vice Chairman from 1987-1991.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/govt/admin/cohen.htm|title=Washingtonpost.com: Politics -- The Administration, William S. Cohen|author=|date=|website=www.washingtonpost.com|accessdate=29 March 2018}} He also participated in the drafting of several notable laws related to defense matters, including the [[Competition in Contracting Act]] (1984), the [[Chapter 30 (G.I. Bill of Rights)|Montgomery G.I. Bill Act]] (1984), the [[Goldwater-Nichols Act]] (1986), the Intelligence Oversight Reform Act (1991), the [[Federal Acquisition Reform Act]] (1996), the Nunn-Cohen Act Amendment creating the [[United States Special Operations Command]],{{cite web|url=http://www.defensemedianetwork.com/stories/from-world-war-ii-to-nunn-cohen-socom-history-part-1/|title=From World War II to Nunn-Cohen - Defense Media Network|author=|date=|website=defensemedianetwork.com|accessdate=29 March 2018}} and the [[Information Technology Management Reform Act]], also known as the [[Clinger-Cohen Act]] (1996). ==Secretary of Defense== Cohen was appointed by President Bill Clinton to the position of Secretary of Defense during Clinton's second term, from 1997 to 2001, an instance of a cabinet appointment that [[List of United States political appointments across party lines|crossed party lines]]. As Secretary of Defense Cohen played a large role in directing the United States military actions in [[Iraq]] and [[Kosovo]], including the dismissal of [[Wesley Clark]] from his post as the [[NATO]] [[Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe|Supreme Allied Commander]]. Both [[Operation Desert Fox]] in Iraq and [[Operation Allied Force]] in Kosovo were launched just months after [[al-Qaeda]] carried out the [[1998 United States embassy bombings|United States embassy bombings]] in [[Dar es Salaam]], [[Tanzania]], and [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]], in 1998. ===Nomination and confirmation=== On December 5, 1996, President Clinton announced his selection of Cohen as secretary of defense. Cohen, a Republican about to retire from the United States Senate, was the "right person," Clinton said, to build on the achievements of [[William Perry]], "to secure the bipartisan support America's armed forces must have and clearly deserve." In responding to his nomination, Cohen said that during his congressional career he had supported a nonpartisan [[national security]] policy and commended the president for appointing a Republican to his cabinet. [[File:Clinton and Cohen meeting at the Pentagon.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Cohen and President [[Bill Clinton]] at [[The Pentagon]], September 1997]] During his confirmation hearings, Cohen said he thought on occasion he might differ with Clinton on specific national security issues. He implicitly criticized the Clinton administration for lacking a clear strategy for leaving [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]] and stated that he thought U.S. troops should definitely be out by mid-1998. He also asserted that he would resist further budget cuts, retain the two regional conflicts strategy, and support spending increases for advanced weapons, even if it necessitated further cuts in military personnel. Cohen questioned whether savings from [[Base Realignment and Closure|base closings]] and acquisition reform could provide enough money for procurement of new weapons and equipment that the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]] thought necessary in the next few years. He supported the expansion of NATO and looked on the proliferation of [[weapons of mass destruction]] as the most serious problem the United States faced. [[File:HowardCohen97.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Cohen and [[Prime Minister of Australia|Australian Prime Minister]] [[John Howard]] at [[The Pentagon]], June 27, 1997]] After [[Advice and consent|confirmation]] by a unanimous Senate vote, Cohen was sworn in as the 20th Secretary of Defense on January 24, 1997. He then settled into a schedule much fuller than he had followed in the Senate. Routinely he arrived at the Pentagon before 7 a.m., received an intelligence briefing, and then met with the [[Deputy Secretary of Defense]] ([[John Hamre]] 1997–2000, [[Rudy de Leon]] 2000–01) and the [[Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff]] (Gen. [[Hugh Shelton]]). The rest of the day he devoted to policy and budget briefings, visits with foreign and other dignitaries, and to what he termed "ABC" meetings at the White House with [[Secretary of State]] [[Madeleine Albright]] and [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]] [[Sandy Berger]] as well as President [[Bill Clinton]]. He also traveled abroad several times during his first months in office. ===Defense budget=== One of Cohen's first major duties was to present to [[United States Congress|Congress]] the Fiscal Year 1998 Defense budget, which had been prepared under Secretary Perry. Cohen requested a budget of $250.7 billion, which represented 3 percent of the nation's estimated gross domestic product for FY 1998. Cohen stressed three top budget priorities: people (recruiting and retaining skilled people through regular military pay raises, new construction or modernization of barracks, and programs for child care, family support, morale, welfare, and recreation), readiness (support for force readiness, training, exercises, maintenance, supplies, and other essential needs), and modernization (development and upgrading of weapon and supporting systems to guarantee the combat superiority of U.S. forces). This meant increasing the funds available for procurement of new systems, with the target set at $60 billion by FY2001. When he presented the FY1998 budget, Cohen noted that he would involve himself with the [[Quadrennial Defense Review]] (QDR), which would focus on the challenges to U.S. security and the nation's military needs over the next decade or more. When the QDR became public in May 1997, it did not fundamentally alter the budget, structure, and doctrine of the military. Many defense experts thought it gave insufficient attention to new forms of warfare, such as terrorist attacks, electronic sabotage, and the use of chemical and biological agents. Cohen stated that the Pentagon would retain the "two regional wars" [[Scenario planning|scenario]] adopted after the end of the [[Cold War]]. He decided to scale back purchases of [[Fighter aircraft|jet fighters]], including the Air Force's [[F-22 Raptor]] and the Navy's [[F/A-18E/F Super Hornet]], as well as Navy surface ships. The review included cutting another 61,700 active duty service members—15,000 in the [[United States Army|Army]], 26,900 in the [[United States Air Force|Air Force]], 18,000 in the [[United States Navy|Navy]], and 1,800 in the [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]], as well as 54,000 reserve forces, mainly in the [[Army National Guard]], and some 80,000 civilians department-wide. Cohen also recommended two more rounds of base closings in 1999 and 2001. The Pentagon hoped to save $15 billion annually over the next few years to make possible the purchase of new equipment and weapon systems without a substantial budget increase above the current level of $250 billion. ===International relations and situations=== [[File:William Cohen and S. R. Nathan at the Istana, Singapore.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Cohen and [[Sellapan Ramanathan]]]] [[File:U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen in South Korea, January 1998.jpg|thumb|left|225px|Cohen, General [[John H. Tilelli, Jr.]], Commander in Chief, United Nations Command/Combined Forces Command/U.S. Forces]] As he settled into office, Cohen faced the question of the expansion of the [[North Atlantic Treaty Organization]], which he supported, and its relationship to Russia. At a summit meeting between President Clinton and [[President of Russia|Russian President]] [[Boris Yeltsin]] in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]], in March 1997, Yeltsin acknowledged the inevitability of broader NATO membership. Two months later he agreed, after negotiations with NATO officials, to sign an accord providing for a new permanent council, to include Russia, the NATO secretary general, and a representative of the other NATO nations, to function as a forum in which Russia could air a wide range of security issues that concerned that country. Formal signing of this agreement would pave the way for a July 1997 invitation from NATO to several nations, probably including [[Poland]], [[Hungary]], and the [[Czech Republic]], to join the organization. The proposed U.S. [[missile defense]] system received attention at the Helsinki summit, where Clinton and Yeltsin agreed to an interpretation of the 1972 [[Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty]] allowing the United States to proceed with a limited missile defense system currently under development. Specifically, Clinton and Yeltsin agreed to distinguish between a national missile defense system, aimed against strategic weapons, not allowed by the ABMT, and a theater missile defense system to guard against shorter range missile attacks. Some critics thought that any agreement of this kind would place undesirable limits on the development of both theater and strategic missile defenses. The Helsinki meeting also saw progress in arms control negotiations between the United States and Russia, a matter high on Cohen's agenda. Yeltsin and Clinton agreed on the need for early Russian ratification of the [[START I|Second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty]] (START II) and negotiation of [[START III]] to make further significant cuts in the strategic nuclear arsenals of both nations. [[File:Yoshiro Mori meets William Cohen 2.jpg|thumb|right|225px|Cohen (left) and Japanese Prime Minister [[Yoshiro Mori]] pose for photographers prior to their meeting at the [[Kantei]] building in Tokyo, Japan, on September 22, 2000.]] The continuation, at least until mid-1998, of the existing peacekeeping mission involving U.S. forces in Bosnia and the possibility that other such missions would arise worried Cohen, who earlier had expressed reservations about such operations. Humanitarian efforts that did not involve peacekeeping, such as in [[Rwanda]] in the recent past, also seemed likely. Other persistent national security problems, including tension with [[Iraq]] in the [[Persian Gulf]] area, [[Libya]] in [[North Africa]], and [[North Korea]] in [[East Asia]], could flare up again, as could the [[Arab–Israeli conflict]]. In preparing future budgets, the challenge would be to find the right mix between money for operation and maintenance accounts on the one hand and modernization procurement funds on the other, while facing the prospect of a flat DoD budget of about $250 billion annually for the next decade or so. A relatively new problem that could affect the DoD budget was [[vertical integration]] in the defense industry. It occurred on a large scale in the 1990s as mergers of major defense contractors created a few huge dominant companies, particularly in the [[aerospace]] industry. They were called vertical because they incorporated most of the elements of the production process, including parts and subcomponents. Cohen and other Pentagon leaders began to worry that vertical integration could reduce competition and in the long run increase the costs of what the Department of Defense had to buy. ===Social issues=== Finally, Cohen had to address social issues that engaged the widest public interest. These issues included the status and treatment of [[lesbian]]s and [[gay]]s in the military, the role of women in combat as well as in other jobs in the services, [[racism]], and [[sexual harassment]]. ==Recent years== [[Image:William Cohen and Janet Langhart 2006.jpg|thumb|left|Cohen and his wife, author [[Janet Langhart]], August 2006]] After leaving the Pentagon in 2001, Cohen founded ''[[The Cohen Group]]'', a business consulting and lobbyist firm, with three Pentagon officials, Bob Tyrer, Jim Bodner, and H.K. Park. Cohen was presented with the [[Woodrow Wilson Awards|Woodrow Wilson Award for Public Service]] by the [[Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars|Woodrow Wilson Center]] of the [[Smithsonian Institution]] on March 7, 2002, in [[New York City]]. On January 5, 2006, he participated in a meeting at the [[White House]] of former Secretaries of Defense and State to discuss United States foreign policy with Bush administration officials. Cohen has written several books, including mysteries, poetry, and (with [[George J. Mitchell|George Mitchell]]) an analysis of the [[Iran-contra affair]]. He is a Chairman Emeritus of the [[US-Taiwan Business Council]]. ''[[The Washington Post]]'' ran an article entitled "From Public Life to Private Business" about Cohen's abrupt transition to the business of Washington lobbying within "weeks of leaving office."May 28, 2006. It discussed the affairs of the Cohen Group in greater detail and while alleging no specific impropriety, took a generally negative view of the former Senator and Secretary of Defense. On August 21, 2006, Cohen's novel, ''Dragon Fire'', was released. The plot revolves around a secretary of defense who contends with a potential [[Nuclear weapon|nuclear]] threat from a foreign country. In December 2006 he released a memoir with his wife, author [[Janet Langhart]], entitled ''Love in Black and White.'' It is a memoir about race, religion, and the love Langhart and Cohen share over similar life circumstances and backgrounds.''Washington Post'', [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/08/17/AR2006081701514.html ''Names & Faces,''] Friday, August 18, 2006; p. C03. On August 22, 2006, Cohen appeared on [[The Daily Show]] to promote his novel.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/watch/tue-august-22-2006/william-cohen|title=The Daily Show with Trevor Noah|author=|date=|website=Comedy Central|accessdate=29 March 2018}} On August 25, 2006, Cohen was interviewed by [[Brian Kilmeade]] on [[Fox & Friends First]], primarily to promote his new novel, but towards the end of the broadcast he said: "I think there should be a commitment to universal service. I think that only a few people are really committed to this war against terrorism.... We ought to have a real call to national service to commit ourselves to some form of public service...to put us on a war footing mentality." [[File:James Mattis and William Cohen 170217-D-GO396-0146 (32957757475).jpg|thumb|right|200px|Cohen with incumbent Defense Secretary [[James Mattis]] in February 2017]] On January 3, 2007, Cohen appeared on [[CNN]] to support [[John Shalikashvili]]'s [[op-ed]] in support of ending the policy known as '[[Don't ask, don't tell]]' saying, "The vast majority of service members are personally comfortable working and interacting with gays and lesbians, and there is only so long that Congress can ignore the evidence".[http://www.gay.com/news/article.html?2007/01/03/4 Ex-Defense Secretary Cohen rips "don't ask"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20070105170850/http://www.gay.com/news/article.html?2007/01/03/4 |date=2007-01-05 }}, Gay.com, January 3, 2007. [[BBC News]] hired Cohen as a world affairs analyst in May 2016. Cohen appears in this capacity on ''[[BBC World News America]]'' and other broadcasts.{{cite news |last=Grinapol |first=Corinne |newspaper=Ad Week |title=William Cohen Joins BBC News as a World Affairs Analyst |date=May 31, 2016 |url=http://www.adweek.com/fishbowldc/william-cohen-joins-bbc-news-as-a-world-affairs-analyst/156532 |accessdate=June 13, 2016}} Cohen and [[Madeleine Albright]] are co-chairing a new "[[Genocide]] Prevention Task Force".{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/world/unitedstates/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12773216|title=Lexington: Preventing genocide|publisher=The Economist|date=December 11, 2008|accessdate=2009-06-08}} Their appointment was criticized by [[Harut Sassounian]]{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/harut-sassounian/secretaries-albright-and-_b_73628.html|title=Harut Sassounian: Secretaries Albright and Cohen Should be Removed from Genocide Task Force|publisher=Huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=2009-06-08|date=March 28, 2008}} and by the [[Armenian National Committee of America]].{{cite web |url=http://www.anca.org/press_releases/press_releases.php?prid=1329 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615220600/http://anca.org/press_releases/press_releases.php?prid=1329 |archivedate=2010-06-15 |df= }} Cohen serves as an Advisory Board member for the [[Partnership for a Secure America]] and is also a member of the ReFormers Caucus of [[Issue One]].{{cite web|url=https://www.issueone.org/reformers/|title=Issue One – ReFormers Caucus|author=|date=|website=www.issueone.org|accessdate=29 March 2018}} In addition, he serves as a board member of the U.S.-China Business Council, having served as vice chairman between 2011-2013, and the U.S.-India Business Council.{{cite web|url=https://www.uschamber.com/william-cohen|title=William Cohen|author=|date=|website=U.S. Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=29 March 2018}} During the [[2016 United States presidential election]], Cohen joined many Republicans in breaking with party ranks to [[List of Republicans opposing Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|oppose]] the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|candidacy]] of Republican nominee [[Donald Trump]]. He endorsed Democratic nominee former [[Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]].{{cite web|title=Republican ex-defense secretary Cohen backs Hillary Clinton|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-cohen-idUSKCN11D2GK}} ==Personal life== Cohen filed for divorce from his first wife, Diana Dunn, on February 15, 1987. On February 14, 1996, Cohen and [[Janet Langhart]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nndb.com/people/451/000051298|title=Janet Langhart|author=|date=|website=www.nndb.com|accessdate=29 March 2018}} were married. Janet had actually refused multiple proposals due to concerns about potential reactions in Senate reelection campaigns of an interracial marriage. Langhart is a former model, [[Boston]] television personality, and [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]] correspondent. Janet Langhart was known as the "First Lady of the Pentagon" during Cohen's tenure as Secretary.{{cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1077/is_1_56/ai_66455756/|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20120527021627/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1077/is_1_56/ai_66455756/|deadurl=yes|title=JANET LANGHART COHEN First Lady Of the Pentagon - Ebony - Find Articl…|author=|date=27 May 2012|archivedate=27 May 2012|website=findarticles.com|accessdate=29 March 2018}} Cohen served as [[Groomsman|Best Man]] in then-Senate Naval Liaison [[John McCain]]'s second wedding ([[Gary Hart]] was a groomsman). McCain later became his Senate colleague.{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/specials/mccain/articles/0301mccainbio-chapter5.html|title=Arizona, the early years|publisher=Azcentral.com|accessdate=2009-06-08}} According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', Cohen was considered a loner in Congress.{{cite news|last1=Clymer|first1=Adam|title=A Bipartisan Voice: William Sebastian Cohen|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/06/us/a-bipartisan-voice-william-sebastian-cohen.html|accessdate=October 9, 2014|publisher=''New York Times''|date=December 6, 1996}} He is a [[Unitarian Universalism|Unitarian Universalist]].{{cite news |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/jpost/access/64129080.html?dids=64129080:64129080&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jan+26%2C+1997&author=HILLEL+KUTTLER&pub=Jerusalem+Post&desc=Cohen+new+Pentagon+chief&pqatl=google |title=Cohen new Pentagon chief|publisher=Pqasb.pqarchiver.com |date=1997-01-26 |accessdate=2009-06-11 |first=Hillel |last=Kuttler}} ===Attack at Holocaust Museum=== {{main|United States Holocaust Memorial Museum shooting}} On the afternoon of June 10, 2009, Cohen was present at the [[U.S. Holocaust Museum]], waiting for his wife [[Janet Langhart]], for the world premiere of her one-act play, ''[[Anne and Emmett]]''. The play imagines a conversation between [[Anne Frank]] and [[Emmett Till]].{{cite web|last=Brevis|first=Vita|url=http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2009/6/10/740907/-Anne-and-Emmett-and-Todays-Shooting|title=State of the Nation|publisher=Daily Kos|accessdate=2009-06-11}} While Cohen waited, an elderly man with a long gun attacked the facility, fatally [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum shooting|shooting]] a security guard before being wounded himself by the other guards. Cohen and Langhart were not injured, and appeared on [[CNN]] that afternoon to tell what they had seen and respond to the shooter's racist beliefs. The man was identified as [[James von Brunn|James W. von Brunn]], 88, of Annapolis, a longtime "hard-core" supremacist whose Internet writings contain extensive criticism against Jews and African Americans.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/10/AR2009061001768.html | work=The Washington Post | first1=Michael E. | last1=Ruane | first2=Paul | last2=Duggan | first3=Clarence | last3=Williams | title=At a Monument of Sorrow, A Burst of Deadly Violence | date=June 11, 2009}} Langhart's play had been promoted in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' the week before, and was being presented in honor of the eightieth anniversary of Anne Frank's birth.[[CNN]] and [[MSNBC]] ongoing live news coverage, June 10, 2009. ==Recent publications== * July 7, 2009, [https://www.forbes.com/2009/07/07/russia-obama-medvedev-nuclear-energy-opinions-contributors-defense.html On Common Ground] ''[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]'' magazine * June 8, 2009, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110613213915/http://www.cohengroup.net/news/op_ed/op_ed060809.cfm Smart Power is Soft Power] ''[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]'' * June 3, 2009, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110613211816/http://www.cohengroup.net/news/op_ed/op_ed060309.cfm Nuclear cooperation with U.A.E. in our interest] ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' * May 28, 2009, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110613211955/http://www.cohengroup.net/news/op_ed/op_ed052809_2.cfm No time to cut missile defense] ''[[The Washington Times]]'' * April 23, 2009, [[File:Yehuda Shinar.jpg|thumb|right|Yehuda Shinar]] '''Yehuda Shinar''' is a [[graphologist]], [[life coach]], and the owner and CEO of the [[Shinar Institute]], established in Israel in 1976. The institute's expertise is in analyzing and evaluating job candidates for managerial positions throughout the world.
In 1996, Shinar established [[Winning Enterprises Ltd]] after studying and investigating how some people seem to achieve a lot in their lives and others do not, especially in the sporting arena. Shinar and his colleagues used this information to develop a strategy for winning, focusing on their way of thinking, decision making dynamic and their one on one strategies.
In the sporting world, Shinar has worked with Sir [[Clive Woodward]] of the [[England]] rugby team, helping them to win the [[Rugby World Cup]], [[Tony Falkner]] of [[Blackburn Rovers]], helping them to win the [[National Academy League]], and the [[Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] football club to help them qualify for the [[UEFA Champions League]] in 2004-2005.
Shinar is also involved in lecturing and fostering winning strategies to organizations within Israel and abroad, including the [[Royal Bank of Scotland]], the [[Scottish Institute of Sport]], [[Capital Radio]] and [[Nat West]].
